title: Brexit deal news explained UK EU withdrawal agreement Theresa May Ireland backstop latest
story: The Prime Minister&rsquos managed to bundle her draft withdrawal agreement with Brussels over the line on Wednesday night after a five-hour marathon Cabinet meeting that sparked rumours of senior resignations and even claimed its first victim the following morning. But in what is considered largely as a victory by Brussels and Downing Street, Mrs May has secured a UK-wide Irish backstop, the insurance policy to prevent a hard border on the island of Ireland. The mechanism became Brexit&rsquos most vexed issue because the EU&rsquos own plan was used as the building blocks for what was agreed by the Prime Minister&rsquos Europe advisor Olly Robbins and his European Commission counterparts Michel Barnier and Sabine Weyand. After proclaiming &ldquono British Prime Minister could accept the terms set out by Brussels, which would have essentially kept Northern Ireland locked in the EU&rsquos customs union and single market for goods, Mrs May has now agreed a UK-wide approach to the backstop.                Brexit news: Customs union membership is now 'basis for the future'                Brexit deal TODAY: What time will Cabinet meet TODAY?When does the Irish backstop come into force?The mechanism will now take shape in the withdrawal agreement as a UK-wide customs union arrangement.This temporary insurance policy will come into force &ldquounless and until a permanent solution to prevent a hard Irish border is found jointly by Brussels and Westminster.Because of the toxicity in the backstop, negotiators have included a review mechanism to avoid it ever being triggered.In July 2020, officials from both sides will come together to make a decision of how to proceed using three potential options.They will either say a UK-EU free trade agreement that avoids a hard Irish border has been agreed and the backstop is no longer needed, if a solution is within reach they can extend the 21-month transition period to allow more time for talks and finally, if all else fails, the backstop will be triggered.Brexit news: Theresa May agrees deal with EU and now must convince her Cabinet (Image: )Will the UK be chained to Brussels forever?Fearful Brexiteers believe accepting a UK-wide customs backstop with no &ldquoindependent review mechanism allows Brussels to essentially keep Britain locked in a start of constant limbo.Under the terms of the UK-wide backstop, Britain would be in a customs union with Brussels and therefore have to follow EU trade rules and be unable to sign independent trade deals in order to maintain a frictionless border.The rumoured backstop agreement can be described as a swimming pool &ndash Great Britain would be in the shallow end while Northern Ireland is in the deep.The EU has insisted the original Northern Ireland-specific backstop is buried deep within the 500-page withdrawal agreement.In theory, this means if the UK Government grows sick of following EU trade rules and customs union membership it could remove Great Britain from backstop but the ultimate fallback would come into play and Northern Ireland would remain solely in the EU&rsquos customs arrangement and single market for goods &ndash creating a border in the Irish Sea.                What is the Brexit backstop? Has Northern Ireland been split from UK?                 Brexit deal TODAY: What time will Cabinet meet TODAY?Does this mean the European Court of Justice will have influence in Britain?Ultimately, the ECJ will be the final arbiter on issues involving EU law that may arise from the Irish backstop agreement.Geoffrey Cox, the Attorney General, has discussed a &ldquojoint arbitration panel to break any future impasse during review negotiations surrounding the backstop.But EU officials believe such panels are not allowed to settle political disputes of this nature and have therefore ensured that the ECJ will play a major role overseeing EU law in Northern Ireland.Questions of interpreting EU law can only be settled by the ECJ, which will leave the Luxembourg-based courts with an important role to play in the UK&rsquos exit from the backstop.Could the backstop become the future trading deal?Alongside the 585-page withdrawal agreement came the publication of a seven-page outline on the political declaration that commits both sides to combining deep regulatory and customs cooperations, building on the single customs territory provided for in the withdrawal agreement.This proclaims that both sides will use the single customs territory &ndash the UK-wide backstop &ndash as the basis for a future relationship.The political declaration says both sides have commit to combining deep regulatory and customs cooperations, building on the single customs territory provided for in the withdrawal agreement.After its publication, Mr Barnier said: &ldquoWe&rsquore drawing the basis for an ambitious partnership which we want, which is a free trade area based on regulatory and customs cooperation in depth and with a &lsquolevel playing field&rsquo.&ldquoOur objective is to abolish customs duties and quotas for all goods based on what we&rsquore proposing in the withdrawal agreement, a single customs territory.&ldquoThere will be no tariffs on goods and indeed it is legitimate for that proposal to be flanked by a level playing field that&rsquos a voluntary deliberate agreement between two parties who respect each other. This agreement offers a basis for future negotiations and that is in our common interest.

May accused of BREXIT BETRAYAL by former chief aide                Rees-Mogg in FEROCIOUS attack on 'UNDIGNIFIED' May Mr Barnier made his own statement in the EU Commission's Berlaymont headquarters, where the Frenchman hailed the agreement as a decisive and crucial step in concluding in these negotiations.His message offered the signal to Mr Tusk that it is now time to convene the special Brexit summit, which is penciled in for November 25.The EU negotiator was cautious when discussing the draft withdrawal agreement and the political declaration of the outline for a framework of the future relationship that runs alongside it.He explained that the 585-page withdrawal document was the result of very intense negotiations that started 17 months ago.The agreement contains the 21-month transition period, the so-called orce bill, citizens' rights guarentees and the thorny Irish backstop.The orce agreement is followed by a seven-page outline on the political declaration that commits both sides to combining deep regulatory and customs cooperations, building on the single customs territory provided for in the withdrawal agreement.Mr Barnier said: &ldquoWe&rsquore drawing the basis for an ambitious partnership which we want, which is a free trade area based on regulatory and customs cooperation in depth and with a &lsquolevel playing field&rsquo.&ldquoOur objective is to abolish customs duties and quotas for all goods based on what we&rsquore proposing in the withdrawal agreement, a single customs territory.&ldquoThere will be no tariffs on goods and indeed it is legitimate for that proposal to be flanked by a level playing field that&rsquos a voluntary deliberate agreement between two parties who respect each other. This agreement offers a basis for future negotiations and that is in our common interest.

to get three things right.&ldquoOur relationship in the EU, our position with the rest of the world and our domestic economic and financial agenda.&ldquoAnd the biggest single problem about this orce settlement is it ties our hands on two of those three areas.&ldquoOur ability to position ourselves globally and on our domestic economic agenda.&ldquoWhen you actually look at that customs for two or three hours last night and in terms of the domestic economic agenda, it ties us forward to 2030 or so.&ldquoThe point is, the 21 months on the transition period we then have this story: His comment was made in a response to a furious tweet by Southwark MP Chuka Umunna after Mr Raab&rsquos resignation this morning. Brexit news: Tusk calls November 25 summit to COMPLETE orce dealThis would imply that Mrs May was largely pulling the strings in the Brexit negotiations all along.Mr Umunna spoke to Sky News this morning, echoing the derision in his earlier tweet.He said: &ldquoSo many people will find this very distasteful because here you have got people like Dominic Raab who were architects of the mess and the chaos that we&rsquore seeing right now, walking off the field leaving others to clear up the mess that they&rsquove created.&ldquoI think many of your viewers, however you voted, will think that is a dereliction of duty.Andrew Neil commented on a vitriolic tweet from Labour's Chuka Umuna (Image: Sky)&ldquoHow dare you people walk off having created this mess and expect others to clear it up.Mr Raab quit just hours after Theresa May appeared outside Downing Street to announce the draft deal had been agreed with the EU.The Brexit Secretary was among ministers said to have raised objections during Wednesday's five-hour Cabinet meeting.He had taken over as Brexit Secretary after David Davis resigned in July over Mrs May's Chequers' proposals.Brexit News: Rees-Mogg threatened the PM in the Commons this morning (Image: UK Parliament)Rumours have continued to swirl in Westminster that the tally of Conservative MPs who have submitted letters of no confidence in Mrs May is about to reach the 48 threshold needed to trigger a vote on her position.Brexiteer Jacob Rees-Mogg put the question directly to the Prime Minister during her address to MPs on Thursday. story: Speaking to BBC News, the Tory backbencher called on the Prime Minister to change her mind on the Brexit deal agreed with the European Union negotiators following Dominic Raab's resignation from his Brexit Secretary post. because he&rsquos been aware of all of these things and has clearly been raising this alarm bells with the Prime Minister but it sounds like he&rsquos been ignored.&ldquoOtherwise I suspect he wouldn&rsquot be in this place.&ldquoThe biggest problem with this deal, which I can&rsquot see how the Government will get over, is that we are locking ourselves into a protection customs union in the hands of the EU in a way that we are not a member of the EU.Brexit news: Iain Duncan Smith calls on May to rethink Brexit deal following Raab's resignation (Image: BBC&bull)&ldquoAt the moment we can get out of NATO, we can get out of the UN as a sovereign nation, but apparently we cannot get out of this customs union agreement unless the EU agrees that we should leave.&ldquoWe have given away the power of being a sovereign nation.The Tory MP added the deal will give the EU the opportunity to make the UK suffer indefinitely until it realises Brexit was a terrible mistake and decides to backtrack on its decision to leave.He added: &ldquoThe problem is we have given away our ability to negotiate new trade deals and what we&rsquore left with is a European Union that will be in no hurry whatsoever to do a deal with us, for the very simple reason that they have us captured in the single union for as long as they wish to have us there.&ldquoThat means that they will let negotiations go on and on and on and we will find ourselves really in the worst of all worlds, which is in the customs union but without any say on its rules, its regulations or on what happens in terms of its interpretation.Dominic Raab's resignation followed that of former junior minister Shailesh Vara and was followed by that of Esther McVey from her Work and Pensions Secretary post.&nbspThe Prime Minister will address the House of Commons later today following Cabinet's ided approval of her draft agreement with the Brussels bloc.&nbspMPs are expected to vote on the deal at the beginning of December, following a newly announced EU summit on the deal on November 25.

story: The Tory Brexiteer said the deal &ldquowill never get through Parliament and insisted the Government will not bully MPs into accepting the Brexit deal.Speaking to BBC News, Mr Francois said: &ldquoWe already know the key components that are in it and it doesn&rsquot represent Brexit. Now we are told we could remain in it and we wouldn&rsquot be allowed to leave it unless the EU deigned to allow us to leave.&ldquoThat is not what the British people voted for. That is not leaving the European Union.Members of Cabinet agreed by a narrow majority on Wednesday to support the Prime Minister&rsquos Brexit deal.Brexit news: Mark Francois said the deal on offer is not Brexit (Image: &bullBBC)In a speech outside of Number 10, the Prime Minister admitted her Cabinet had faced difficult choices, particularly over the so-called Northern Ireland backstop insurance policy to avoid a hard border with the Irish republic.Mrs May also had a stern warning for MPs and said they could either accept her deal or risk remaining in the EU.She said: This deal which delivers on the vote of the referendum, which brings back control of our money, laws and borders ends free movement protects jobs, security and our union or leave with no deal - or no Brexit at all.Mr Francois hit back at the comments and said MPs will not accept bullying and insisted the deal will never be accepted by MPs.He said: &ldquoIt&rsquos Project Fear again and if they try to bully us they will find that we are made of sterner stuff. We had all this before the referendum.&ldquoWe were told that if the British people had the temerity to vote to govern themselves, that unemployment would go up by half a million, that house prices would collapse, the economy would go into recession. What&rsquos happened?&ldquoThe economy is still growing, we have got the lowest unemployment since 1975 and house prices are broadly stable. So, my point is, if they try to bully us on the Conservative backbencher, they don&rsquot understand who we are. We will never betray our country. We will never vote for this.He added: &ldquoThis will never ever get through.Soon after the Prime Minister&rsquos statement on Wednesday evening, the Government published the 585-page withdrawal agreement and seven-page future relationship declaration.The draft deal reveals that in July 2020, both the EU and UK will hold a joint review of the position before making one of three choices: deciding a trade deal supersedes the need for the backstop, a limited extension to the transition period or trigger the Irish border backstop.Brexiteers are likely to be left infuriated by the lack of an independent review clause, which will allow the UK to unilaterally quit the backstop.The backstop will only able to be ended &ldquojointly by both sides and will apply until that moment is reached.

title: brexit resignations full list resigns brexit deal suella braverman Anne Marie Trevelyan
story: Suella Braverman quit the position on Thursday morning, just hours after Dominic Raab quit in response to Theresa May's new deal proposal.Mrs Braverman was Mr Raab's aide and also worked for David Davis before Mr Raab took over as predecessor. Mrs Braverman tweeted her resignation letter at 10.22am on Thursday morning. She tweeted the letter with the statement: It is with deep regret and after reflection that I have had to tender my resignation today as a Brexit Minister.                Brexit news: Who is Esther McVey? Why has she quit? Resignation letterThank you for the opportunity.I look forward to working to support Brexit from the Backbenches. This has not been an easy decision.&nbspMrs Braverman&nbspsaid the proposed Northern Ireland backstop is not what the British people voted for, and inssisted it threatened to break up the United Kingdom.Her letter read: Dear Prime Minister,Ms Braverman quit shortly after her boss Dominic Raab left office (Image: )This is a difficult letter to write. One which I never expected to compose. It has been an immense honour to support you in delivering the historic opportunity of leaving the EU as a Parliamentary Under Secretary of State at the Department for Exiting the European Union.It has, in many ways, been a dream job which I have enjoyed tremendously. However, despite my strenuous attempts, I now find myself unable to sincerely support the deal agreed yesterday by Cabinet. It is therefore with deep regret that I tender my resignation.My reasons are simple. Firstly, the proposed Northern Ireland Backstop is not Brexit. It is not what the British people - or my constituents - voted for in 2016.It prevents an unequivocal exit from a customs union with the EU. This robs the UK of the main competitive advantages from Brexit. Without a unilateral right to terminate or a definite time limit to the Backstop, our numerous promises to leave the customs union will not be honoured.Mrs Braverman quit her position shortly after her former boss Dominic Raab (Image: TWITTERSUELLABRAVERMANMP)17.4 million people voted for the UK to leave the EU in our own sovereign way and at a time of our choosing. The Backstop renders this impossible and generations of people will see this as betrayal.Secondly, the Backstop proposals set out different regulatory regimes for Northern Ireland and Great Britain threatening to break up our precious Union. I am confident - having met with customs professionals in my role at the Department - that this could have been avoided.Throughout this process, I have compromised. I have put pragmatism ahead of idealism and understand that concessions are necessary in a negotiation. I have kept faith in the ultimate destination to justify an uncomfortable journey.However I have reached a point where I feel that these concessions do not respect the will of the people - the people who put us here and whom we humbly serve. We must not let them down.Mr Raab quit in protest of Mrs May's new draft porposal (Image: )I thoroughly enjoyed working at the Department and have been supported by excellent civil servants. To them, I am grateful.Thank you for the opportunity. I have immense respect for the way in which you have conducted yourself during these very difficult times.I know how extremely hard you have worked to serve our national interest.I look forward to working to deliver Brexit in the best possible way from the Backbenches.Her resignation comes as another blow to Mrs May's cabinet, which has so far seen a handful of resignations.Many commentators are seeing the resignations as a threat to Mrs May's grip on leadership.Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab - who only took over in the summer after David Davis resigned in protest over the Prime Minister's withdrawal strategy - said he cannot in good conscience support the terms proposed for our deal with the EU.Esther McVey announced she was resigning as Work and Pensions Secretary as she could not defend a deal which meant the UK handing over control to the EU.                POUND PLUMMETS: Strategist warns of THREE 'very extreme' options                IDS 'DEVASTATED' over Raab resignation as he urges May to think againAddressing MPs in the House of Commons, Theresa May paid tribute to the two ministers.Mrs May said: Delivering Brexit involves difficult choices for all of us. We do not agree on all those choices, but I respect their views.The Brexit talks are about acting in the national interest and that means making what I believe are the right choices, not the easy choices.We can choose to leave with no deal, we can risk no Brexit at all, or we can choose to unite and support the best deal that can be negotiated.Mrs Braverman is the latest minister to quit Theresa May's cabinet (Image: EXPRESS)International Trade Secretary Liam Fox also batted off suggestions he should resign over the Prime Minister's draft EU withdrawal agreement.MPs goaded Dr Fox at trade questions over the deal, which was revealed by Number 10 last night, telling him the terms contradicted many of his previous pledges.The calls came as Work and Pensions Secretary Esther McVey announced she was quitting following the resignation of Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab.Anne-Marie Trevelyan also announced she was quitting as an unpaid parliamentary aide in the Department for Education shortly after Mrs May made her announcement.At around 9.00am Thursday morning,&nbspShaliesh Vara has quit as Northern Ireland minister over the Brexit draft agreement.&nbspMr Vara said he &ldquocannot support the agreement, as it does not fully deliver on the result of the referendum.This is a breaking story. More to follow.

story: Theresa May&rsquos deal with the EU has sparked chaos in Westminster with Dominic Raab, Esther McVey, Suella Braverman and other junior ministers resigning in protest. Will Theresa May be forced out as PM?                This deal is BETTER than Norway AND Canada: May FIGHTS for BEST Mr Wells, who is not one of the 10 members of the British parliament whose votes Mrs May needs, told Irish broadcaster RTE: What's absolutely clear is that this deal is dead and my prediction is that Theresa May will not be the prime minister of the UK by Christmas.In a fiery clash in the Commons today, The DUP&rsquos deputy leader Nigel Dodds tore into the Prime Minister over her deal's handling of Northern Ireland.He told MPs: I could today stand here and take the Prime Minister through the list of promises and pledges she made to this house and to us, privately, about the future of Northern Ireland in the future relationship with the EU.BREXIT DEAL LIVE: Theresa May stands on BRINK - 'Britain wants us to GET THIS DONE!&rsquoBrexit news: Theresa May will be removed as Prime Minister by Christmas, a DUP member said (Image: PA)But I fear it would be a waste of time since she clearly doesn't listen.Mr Dodds, the DUP's leader in Westminster, went on to praise the five ministers who quit on Thursday morning, saying: The choice is now clear: we stand up for the United Kingdom, the whole of the United Kingdom, the integrity of the United Kingdom, or we vote for a vassal state with the breakup of the United Kingdom, that is the choice.A group of Northern Ireland politicians are meeting with the Taoiseach in Dublin to discuss the draft Brexit deal.Sinn Fein's leader for Northern Ireland Michelle O'Neill, SDLP leader Colm Eastwood, The Alliance Party's Stephen Farry and Green Party leader Steven Agnew are attending a joint meeting with Mr Varadkar from 10am.&lsquoMay is FINISHED!' Theresa May to face vote of NO CONFIDENCE, former MP claimsBrexit news: The DUP's Jim Wells (R) said the Brexit deal is dead (Image: )Outside Dublin's government buildings, Mr Eastwood said that difficult days lay ahead for Mrs May, but the group's focus was on Northern Ireland.We have to make sure the backstop is fully backed, and that's what we're focused on, protecting people across this island, he said.I think people should take some time to read the full implications of what this will mean.Ms O'Neill said that the group in Dublin represented the majority of Northern Ireland on a cross-community basis.She said: It's a very fluid situation, and I think it'll be a very interesting day.For us, we want to remain in the customs union and the single market and we want protections for the Good Friday Agreement, our message is as consistent today as it was yesterday.BREXIT BUST-UP: Theresa May has FIERY ROW with DUP's Arlene Foster over withdrawal deal                Nigel Farage GLEE at Raab's Brexit resignation - 'Let's have another                POUND PLUMMETS: Strategist warns of THREE 'very extreme' optionsMr Varadkar announced he would meet with the Northern Ireland parties on Wednesday night. However, the&nbspDUP&nbspand Ulster Unionist parties are not in attendance.The Taoiseach added he had not spoken to DUP leader Arlene Foster on Wednesday but said: The door is always open and the phone is always on.Just over 12 hours after Mrs May announced her team of top ministers had agreed to the terms of the draft agreement, Brexit minister Mr Raab and work and pensions minister Ms McVey quit, saying they could not support it.Their departure, and the resignations of two junior ministers, shakes Mrs May's ided government.Mr Raab is the second Brexit secretary to quit over May's plans to leave the European Union, the biggest shift in British policy in more than 40 years.Mr Raab said: Above all, I cannot reconcile the terms of the proposed deal with the promises we made to the country in our manifesto at the last election.Theresa May meets Jeremy Corbyn as she APPEALS for Labour to support her Brexit dealThis is, at its heart, a matter of public trust.EU leaders are ready to meet on November 25 to sign off on the orce deal, or Withdrawal Agreement, but the drama is in London with some lawmakers openly questioning whether the government will survive.One eurosceptic lawmaker in Mrs May's Conservative Party said more colleagues were either putting in letters to trigger a no confidence vote in her leadership or were increasingly minded to do so.A challenge is triggered if 48 Conservatives write such letters. May could be toppled if 158 of her lawmakers vote against her.The Labour Party said the Government was falling apart.Jon Trickett, a member of Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn's senior team, said: Theresa May has no authority left and is clearly incapable of delivering a Brexit deal that commands even the support of her cabinet, let alone parliament and the people of our country.

story: This is according to a document from the World Trade Organisation (WTO), providing the latest blow to Brussels and a sign of how global trade powers are intensifying demands over the UK&rsquos imminent exit from the bloc should be managed - both short and long-term. It also marks yet another hurdle in the plan from the European Union and Britain to untangle their WTO commitments post-Brexit, increasing the likelihood of a huge showdown at the global trade body. The document, obtained by Bloomberg and discussed at a WTO meeting in Geneva on Monday, was signed by Argentina, Australia, Brazil, Canada, China, Mexico, New Zealand, Paraguay, Taiwan, Thailand, the US and Uruguay.                EU kickstart CRUCIAL Brexit talks to decide Britain's WTO futureIt said: &ldquoWe urge the EU to provide further assurances to members that it will provide clarity on how it intends to account for UK-EU trade that it will provide for negotiated outcomes that maintain the quality and level of access currently enjoyed to the EU and that appropriate compensation will be offered where this access is not maintained.&ldquoGiven their considerable, unprecedented scale and scope, these changes are of general and systemic interest to the WTO membership.The 12 countries are furious with how the EU plans to split sensitive import quotas with Britain when it leaves the bloc in March 2019.According to the document, the nations said Brussels has not made any new WTO commitments regarding the future trading relationship between itself and the UK.EU news: The US and China have demanded assurances from Brussels (Image: )Tariff-rate quotas (TRQs) define the volume of sensitive goods, such as meat and cheese, that other World Trade Organisation (WTO) members can export to Europe.They set the amounts of goods that can be imported at low or zero tariffs, as opposed to full WTO rates that can often exceed 100 percent.Last year, Brussels and London came up with a joint plan that involved iding the current quotas based on consumption patterns.This means the UK would take a larger quota for products such as New Zealand lamb, for example, where it accounts for much of the European Union demand.                Fisherman in extraordinary rant as sector stages mass protest                'It's Britain versus EU!' UK Fishermen FURIOUS at Brussels over quotasEU news: TRQs are particularly valuable to agricultural importers, such as New Zealand (Image: )Both parties want endorsement of the plan from the WTO before Brexit takes effect from March 29, 2019.But according to the document, the 12 countries objecting to the plan claim the joint TRQ proposal &ldquoamounts to a reduction in the quality and level of access provided by the EU to WTO members that could &ldquoaffect a globally-significant volume of trade.WTO members don&rsquot have the power to force the EU and Britain to provide market concessions, but they can block certification of their schedule of concessions and trigger WTO dispute settlement proceedings into the issue.One official told the Financial Times that Australia warned at the meeting splitting TRQs risked being too small to be commercially viable, while the US rejected the proposals on the basis that exporters would be worse off.EU news: The defiance from 12 countries is the latest blow to Brussels in Brexit negotiations (Image: )Both the EU and Britain have been working together over recent months around how to share out the TRQs, which are particularly valuable to agricultural exporters such as Argentina and New Zealand, and also the powerful farm lobby in the US.It is also a hugely important issue for Brussels and London, as the result of talks will determine how much competition farmers from within the EU and specifically the UK will face.But failure to find a solution at the WTO over how to split the TRQs could even trigger legal challenges from several of the EU&rsquos trading partners.In a further blow, negotiations on the general market access the UK will provide other WTO members and on the UK&rsquos membership of an international agreement on public procurement are reportedly progressing slower than anticipated.

as Work and Pensions Secretary on November , , over the PM’s soft Brexit deal with the EU.The Liverpool-born MP was described as the most “aggressive” opponent to May’s orce agreement during a cabinet meeting the day before she resigned.In her resignation letter, McVey told the Prime Minister that she could “no longer support” the deal, reports the .She wrote: “Repeatedly you have said that we must regain control of our money, our borders and our laws and develop our own independent trade policy.I have always supported you to deliver on those objectives.“Even after Chequers when you knew I shared the concerns of a very signicant number of colleagues, I believed that we could still work collectively to honour the will of the British people and secure the right outcome for the future of our country.“This deal fails to do this.” In , Labour Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell refused to apologise for saying McVey should be lynched.Two years earlier he called, then jobs minister, Esther McVey a stain on humanity because of disability benefit cuts.The staunch Jeremy Corbyn ally stood by his insult and said it was OK to express honest anger.Ms McVey accused him of whipping up a culture of bullying and linking politics with violence.

title: next prime minister latest odds jacob rees mogg michael gove
story: If she is pushed out by her warring party, here are the candidates most likely to take over.Boris Johnson was the frontrunner to replace Theresa May in No, but has now slipped back to third favourite.Will the next Prime Minister even be a Tory A snap election could be on the cards following a string of high profile Tory resignations following Mrs Mays soft Brexit deal with EU leaders in November, .That could mean Labours Jeremy Corbyn is whisked into Downing Street.Heres the latest odds from Ladbrokes.Former Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson is still a hugely popular figure among Tory grassroots and the general public.He drew a huge crowd to hear him bash Theresa Mays Brexit plans in a barnstorming speech at the Tory conference in Birmingham.Boris quit as Foreign Secretary on July  in a killer blow to Mays government.He walked out just hours after she lost Brexit Secretary David Davis over her Chequers plan to keep close ties to Brussels.But many MPs appear to have turned against him, meaning he might struggle to get on the ballot.His aborted leadership bid in  was scuppered by his friend Michael Gove, severely damaging his electoral brand.And his hopes could be dashed by reports of a close friendship with a blonde Tory aide and his orce from we Marina.The bookies have recently been giving Jeremy Corbyn strong odds as the nations most likely next Prime Minister.The Labour leader has had to fight constant opposition from his own MPs including a leadership contest after just a year.But the party has swung behind him after a much stronger than expected  General Election when Labour picked up  seats and Mrs May lost her majority.Although the fabled youthquake of support from younger voters did not happen, Labour is enjoying relatively strong support in opinion polls.He hopes to force a general election by voting down Mrs Mays Brexit deal, and has boasted he would win.The Home Secretary is the current bookies favourite among the Conservatives.Mr Javid was appointed Home Secretary in the wake of the Windrush scandal and the resignation of Amber Rudd.A known Eurosceptic, Mr Javid ended up backing Remain during the EU referendum but is popular among the Tory parliamentary party.Some of his statements in recent months and his backing for a harder Brexit have been taken as signs he is pitching for the leadership.The MP for Bromsgrove in Worcestershire is a former managing director from Deutsche Bank.The former Brexit secretary quit the cabinet in protest over Theresa Mays soft orce deal with the EU.He played a prominent role in the Leave campaign and previously served as a Justice minister.Before he went into politics he was a lawyer, working on EU and World Trade Organisation Law.His appointment was welcomed by Leave-backing MPs.But his former personal assistant branded him a bullying Mr Nasty after she was sacked for leading a double le as an escort.Mr Hunt was the longest-serving Health Secretary in British history before replacing Boris as Foreign Secretary.He left the Department of Health after securing a £bn funding increase for the NHS.Mr Hunt is known to have leadership aspirations and now says he backs Brexit despite campaigning for Remain during the referendum.David Davis quit as Brexit secretary on July , , with a devastating letter warning Mrs May her proposal would leave the UK in a weak negotiating position with Brussels.He has since launched a series of attacks on Mrs Mays strategy, and led a Tory rebellion to ditch the Chequers plan.He called on Cabinet ministers to rise up and kill off the plans.Furious Tories have demanded Mr Davis be installed as interim leader to save true Brexit.Davis was rated as a   outsider but his odds have recently dropped.Jacob Rees-Mogg, the Latin-fluent millionaire financier and MP for North East Somerset, has emerged as the leading Brexiteer on the backbenches.He has won a huge public profile despite not being a minister and is loved by Tory activists.Rees-Mogg has also garnered a surprise following among many young Tories - including Jungle Queen Georgia Toffolo, who called him a sex god.Devout Catholic Rees-Mogg has made no secret of his socially conservative views, including being anti-abortion and against gay marriage.His plummy tones, double-breasted suits and traditional manner have earned him the nickname The Honourable Member for the Nineteenth Century.The Environment Secretary has achieved a remarkable turnaround since kning Boris Johnson during the  leadership contest.His support among party members dropped through the floor and it seemed his chances were gone for ever.But Mr Gove, who led the Leave campaign in the EU referendum, has rebranded himself as an ecowarrior as Environment Secretary.He has also thrown his full support behind Theresa Mays Brexit plan, winning him friends among MPsnot the party faithful.Though an unlikely candidate at the time, the Brexit campaigner reached the final two of the  leadership contest.She withdrew over ill-judged remarks about Theresa May not being a mother.She is now Leader of the House, and survived in post despite reports Mrs May was planning to cut dead wood in her January reshuffle.Mrs Leadsom had a role in the downfall of Sir Michael Fallon after she accused him of lewd sexual comments.The popular and savvy leader of the Scottish Conservatives has been touted as the potential saviour of the Tories in Westminster.But Ruth has said repeatedly she wants to focus on Scotland and as she is not an MP she currently is not eligible to stand as leader of the UK party.In September  she declared she never wants to be Prime Minister.She will also be putting politics on the back burner for a while as she has just had a baby. Mrs May was humiliated when her snap election backfired in , costing the party its Commons majority.Critics in her own party are circling over her handling of Brexit while a number of cabinet ministers resigned on November , , over her soft orce deal with the EU.She could be forced out MPs demand her exit and she loses a subsequent vote.There would then be a Tory leadership campaign, with the winner crowned PM.Alternatively, Mrs May could lose a vote of confidence in the Commons, leading to her government falling.In theory, the Queen could ask the Labour leader to form a minority government, but the numbers in the Commons would make it impossible for him to govern.There could well be a fresh General Election with both major parties trying to secure a parliamentary majority.

title: what brexit backstop plan theresa may eu irish border
story: Heres our guide to the plan and what it means for Northern Ireland and its border with the Republic of Ireland.The backstop plan is essentially a safety netthere is no Brexit trade deal.The backstop will see Britain remain in the customs union for as long as necessary until an alternative way of keeping the border open is found.Mrs May wants the UK to have the right to end the backstop at will - but the EU has warned that would render the mechanism pointless.It would ensure that no tarfs, quotas, rules of origin or customs processes would be applied to UK-EU trade.At the same time the UK would be able to strike free trade agreements with other countries.On November , thereported that Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab demanded the right to pull Britain out of the EU’s Irish backstop after just three months.The paper claimed the hardline pitch to the Irish government “stunned” Irish officials.Its claimed Mr Raab’s proposal was put to the Irish deputy prime minister Simon Coveney in a private meeting in London.However, the Irish Prime Minister told Theresa May that he will not accept a Brexit deal which gives the UK the unilateral power to halt backstop arrangements for the border with Northern Ireland.The EU has suggested a backstop that would see Northern Ireland staying in the customs union, the EU VAT system and parts of the single market.This will essentially draw a customs border down the middle of the Irish Sea, potentially damaging the union of the UK.Mrs May has suggested a backstop that will see all of the UK aligned with the EU customs union for a limited time after .Brussels has two issues with Mays plan.The first is that May wants the backstop to come to an end after a certain time period the EU thinks this would be self-defeating as its possible no solution for the Irish border would be found.The EU also thinks this risks leaving Britain benefiting from the customs union and single market for years after Brexit - reaping all the benefits without having any of the obligations that full membership would entail.In June  European leaders said Britain was running out of time to do a deal because of the unsolved border problem.In July Theresa May quoted Shakespeare as she insisted the UK would not be broken up with a border down the Irish Sea. Theresa May has told EU leaders she is looking at ways of keeping Britain under their rules for at least another year as part of efforts to break the Brexit deadlock.Addressing the  national bosses at a tense summit in Brussels on the night of October , the PM said she is “ready to consider” extending the  month transition period after the UK leaves the EU next March.The potentially incendiary move has been drawn up by the EU’s chief negotiator Michel Barnier to try to end a bitter impasse over the Irish border.It would mean abiding by all Brussels rules until December  at the earliest.The news comes after talks on Sunday, October , hit a brick wall once again, as the issue of the Irish border continues to cause a headache for Theresa May.Theresa May has insisted any backstop arrangement must apply to the UK as a whole so not to create a border in the Irish Sea.However, talks broke down after the EU had insisted on a second backstop arrangement - just involving Northern Ireland -the UKs version wasnt ready in time, according to Downing Street sources. Mrs May dubbed the continuing row with Brussels over how to avoid a hard border in Ireland as “the one real sticking point left, but a considerable one”.The Democratic Unionist Party has vowed to oppose any new checks on goods passing between Great Britain and Northern Ireland.Irelands Foreign Minister, Simon Coveney, said that EU Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier indicated that the European Union will allow extra time for talks about the border.Mr Coveney said he was frustrated and disappointed that it was going to take more time than people had hoped.On November , , the PM faced crunch Cabinet showdowns with her ministers where she will set out the details of the agreement she struck with Brussels the previous day.A number of pro-Brexit ministers are feared to be on the brink of walking out over the deal.They believe it would leave Britain tied to the EU customs union for years to come, because of the controversial Irish backstop arrangement.If the Cabinet does block Mrs Mays deal, she could find her position is untenable - leading to a Tory leadership crisis.

title: dominic raab new brexit secretary david davis resigned
story: Heres everything you need to know about the former Cabinet minister.The Tory MP and Brexiteer, , played a prominent role in the Leave campaign in .He served as housing minister and as a justice minister before his promotion to the Cabinet.Before going into politics he was a lawyer, working on EU and World Trade Organisation law, making him a good fit for the crucial role leading the Department for Exiting The EU.He began his Westminster career at the Foreign Office in , and led the British team at The Hague dedicated to bringing war criminals to justice.He also advised on the Arab-Israeli Conflict, the EU and Gibraltar, before being hired by David Davis – the man he replaced – in .Raab worked as Mr Davis chief of staff while he served as shadow home secretary, until he was elected to Parliament in  as MP for Esher and Walton.Dominic was born in  to a Czech-born Jewish father, who came to Britain in  as a refugee.He studied law at Oxford and then Cambridge before becoming a solicitor.Raab is married to Erika Rey, a Brazilian marketing executive, and the pair live in Thames Ditton in Surrey with their two children.On November , , Raab quit Theresa Mays Cabinet over the PMs compromised orce deal which she agreed with the EU earlier that week.He said he couldnt support her agreement because it would give the EU a veto over Britains future.Mr Raab warned: I cannot in good conscience support the terms proposed for our deal with the EU.But he insisted he has enduring respect for Mrs May and praised the PM for fighting through dficult times.In his resignation letter, Raab wrote: I cannot support the proposed deal for two reasons. First I believe that the regulatory regime proposed for Northern Ireland presents a very real threat to the integrity of the United Kingdom.Second, I cannot support an indefinite backstop arrangement, where the EU holds a veto over our ability to exit.Above all, I cannot reconcile the terms of the proposed deal with the promises we made to the country in our manesto at the last election. title: brit trying to claim universal credit told he must take his first day off at his new job to go to a job hunting meeting
story: Geraint Jones, , who lives in Reading, has been trying to get help on the new benefits system after he lost his job earlier this year.He’s managed to find a new one and is due to start in a couple of weeks, but has bizarrely been told he must attend a mandatory job-hunting meeting at his local job centre anyway, or he won’t be entitled to a penny.The IT sales worker, who has also served in the RAF, told The Sun Online: “They said I still need to come in and meet a job coach.“I’m away for a few days visiting my elderly mum so they told me to take my first day off at my new job - to help me get a job!“It’s just ridiculous.”Geraint, known to pals as Taff, fears he will go into debt as a result of being unable to get help on Universal Credit during the days he’s out of work.He was trying to claim the Jobseekers’ Allowance and Housing Benefit parts of Universal Credit - just to help him for  days when he was between jobs.He waited until his final pay cheque had come through from his old job - another trap that many other claimants can fall into - to make sure his benefit wouldn’t be affected.And after spending weeks hunting, he was delighted to find a new job.But Taff’s pay will likely outweigh any benefits he could get anyway, meaning he won’t be able to get any help for the time he’s been out of work.“I’m quite worried about the next few weeks,” he said.“They say the system encourages people to work as quickly as possible but it’s in my financial interest to not start work until next month so I’ll be entitled to benefits.“It seems designed to do as much as they can not to pay out.“I’m just an ordinary people in a bit of a bad situation and just want some help to get me through.“I served in the forces, I want my little bit back that I’m entitled to.”Now Taff thinks hell not be able to claim the £ to help with his housing and bills, that Universal Credit staff thought he could be entitled to.Taffs just one of many who have had problems on the new system, which many say has pushed them into debt.But officials said it was too late now to half the whole process - even though millions of Brits have been affected by the problems.The Chancellor revealed a new funding boost which will help Brits on the new scheme, but it wont kick in for millions until at least next April.The DWP say any new claimant needs to attend a job centre interview to discuss what they need to do to find work - and whether they are entitled to cash help when they are in it.A spokesperson said: When applying for Universal Credit, people will be asked to meet with their Work Coach to agree a Claimant Commitment.If they already have a job this commitment might include ways to progress in work and increase their pay, rather than looking for work.”

title: labour mp lives in social housing
story: Shadow development secretary Kate Osamor has faced intense criticism after it emerged that she promoted her son in his House of Commons job, regardless of his conviction for having £, of Class A drugs with intent to supply at Bestival in Dorset last year.Now the Sun on Sunday can reveal that Ms Osamor and her son Ishmael, , are living in social housing in Tottenham, north London - despite their earnings classing them ineligible by council guidelines.Haringey Council documents from  state that households earning in excess of £, are not eligible to apply for a social housing property.And it has been reported that , people are waiting for social housing in the borough - one of the poorest in Britain - and a further , are living in temporary accommodation due to the limited supply of properties.Ms Osamor, a close ally of Jeremy Corbyn, is paid a salary of £, plus expenses. Since being elected an MP in  she has also benefitted from £, of travel and accommodation on visits to countries including India and Nigeria.Her son Ishmael is working for her as her chief of staff and is paid up to £,. And before he resigned from Haringey council last month he was entitled to claim at least £, a year in allowances from the council.Ishmael was previously a director of two clothing companies and a second hand car sales business which was dissolved in September this year. He pleaded guilty to the drug charges on October , having brought ecstasy, cocaine, ketamine and cannabis to the music festival.Ishmael was spared prison after his barrister persuaded prosecutors he was not planning to make a profit from his £, haul of drugs.Judge Stephen Climie said the -year-old was lucky to avoid a four-year prison term and sentenced him to  hours of unpaid work instead and to pay £ prosecution costs.Osamor pleaded guilty to four drugs charges after his barrister Mohsin Zaidi struck a deal with the Crown Prosecution Service at Bournemouth Crown Court.The former Labour councillor was caught with g of ecstasy – a class A drug blamed for a string of deaths at music festivals – as well .g of cocaine, .g of ketamine and a trace of cannabis at Bestival in .Ms Osamor has denied wrongdoing in the row over her son.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: stop praying silence from charles
story: But close your eyes and imagine, for a moment, knowing from childhood exactly what job you are going to do — because you have no choice about whether or not you actually want to do it.And imagine, then, having to wait for that job to start until you are the age when most people are hanging up their work boots and starting to claim a pension.It’s impossible, right  But the Prince of Wales — the man who was born to be king — has known since the age of four that he would one day have to step into his mother’s shoes. And what a mother.They say no one is irreplaceable but I think she is — which must be such a lot of pressure for him. In short, he has spent his entire le waiting for his mum to die before he can start his dream job.And in the meantime his le, in some ways, is on hold. He was not allowed to marry the woman he loved and was instead forced into a loveless marriage.And every time he so much as expresses an opinion about anything, he is denounced as being “meddling”.So it’s no wonder that in Prince, Son And Heir, the BBC documentary this week marking his th birthday, Charles was quick to quell concerns that he would be a “meddling” or activist king, saying: “I’m not that stupid.”Declaring the role of sovereign and heir to be dferent, he said he is aware of the constraints he will encounter as king, and says his behaviour will change.I can see why he is saying that, given the amount of criticism that has come his way over the years. But when you think that he was campaigning about issues such as the environment and single-use plastic long before anyone  got on the bandwagon, it might be better to see him as a trailblazer than a meddler.I admire that he has a voice.And when he is king I think he should use it — not be silenced by the pressure of the role.He has a very broad range of knowledge and he is absolutely passionate. We live in a society where everyone has their say — so why shouldn’t he In fact, I thinkhe visited Europe he might help with Brexit.There is no doubt the Queen is a hard act to follow — when the time comes, that is. Now Charles is  he is the longest serving heir to the throne in history. And he may have years to go, as the Queen looks and sounds fantastic .But we should stop maligning Charles and start supporting him.He is a good man and there is no doubt he is dedicated to the job. He is mature enough to know how to do the job well and he certainly knows what is expected of him.He has brought up two fantastic sons that any parent would be proud of.And he really is passionate about changing the world for the better.It has been more than  years since he set up his Prince’s Trust charity.Last year alone it helped nearly , young people get into education, training and jobs. It is simply fantastic.He is deeply committed to his fantastic we, who is very down-to-earth and great fun .He is also passionate about promoting women’s issues, so whatever you think of him you must give him credit for that.I believe very strongly in the monarchy. I would do anything the Queen asked me to do.The Royal Family are a great thing for our country and something to be very proud of.In a world of increasing uncertainty, they are this country’s rock and foundation. We should all get behind Charles and celebrate him as our future king.Apart from anything , we need all the stability we can get. ANYONE living in London will be unsurprised to hear that there are now a record number of people sleeping rough there.Figures show there were , rough sleepers in the capital between July and September – the first time the total has exceeded , in a three-month period.It’s awful and it’s shocking to see people sitting in the cold begging for money.And it’s hard to know how to help. Of course, the temptation is to give money but obviously that’s just a short-term fix.Night shelters are a good short-term solution. Buthomeless people don’t get involved with a network that can really help them, it’s unlikely their circumstances will ever change.My husband Paul volunteers with the fantastic charity West London Mission . It offers homeless people a hot shower, new clothes, a meal and a decent night’s sleep.But it also offers access to project workers who will help people change their circumstances.Its aim is to empower and help homeless people become part of a community, because that’s the start of them getting off the streets, into accommodation, then into work.There are so many reasons that people become homeless. Some have lost their job and can’t afford rent, or they’ve fallen out with family and turn to drink and drugs.They might have mental or physical health problems, a history of abuse or a dficult childhood moving between foster homes.But where there is le, there is hope. Paul has been working with one guy who was homeless and hopelessly addicted to drugs.But, over time, he has got clean, found a place to live and, last week, got a job at a restaurant, which is what he was doing before he got involved in drugs.He’s got his le back, basically. It does happen.Soyou are worried about homelessness, think about donating to an organisation such as WLM. Better yet, volunteer your time and skills.Even just helping someone to fill out a form, which can be incredibly dficult for some people, can make a huge dference and is so rewarding.TODAY is Remembrance Day and I wear my poppy with pride. This year I will particularly recognise all the true heroes from World War One. I thank them for their service, and remember we are always in their debt.It is so important we never forget the sacrice they made and the bravery they showed.I doubt there will ever be another generation like them. AS a rule, I like to live and let live. But I really had to roll my eyes at the story of -year-old Dutch pensioner Emile Ratelband, “who identies as a -year-old” and is fighting to legally change his age by  years so he can get more work and attract more women on Tinder.Emile, above, was born on March , , but says he feels at least  years younger and wants to change his birth date to March , .His argument is thattransgender people are allowed to change sex, he should be allowed to change his date of birth because doctors said he has the body of a -year-old.So does that meanI feel like a supermodel inside, I can I get my job title legally amended Or maybe at  I could identy as  so I can have access to my pension SO the six men arrested for burning an effigy of Grenfell Tower are in hiding and relying on friends and relatives to bring in food and drink. Still, they are yet to speak out – or apologise.What beggars belief is not just that these sick men thought that no one would notice nor care when this footage emerged on social media – but really that they are unhinged enough to do it in the first place.I’m pretty sure about one thing, though. No matter what consequences they will face for their actions from the law, they will never, ever live this down in the eyes of the world – and nor should they.I’m talking about Michael Douglas, . When he was awarded with a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame for more than  years in the entertainment industry, he gave his father, Kirk, a kiss on the lips to celebrate.In my experience there comes an age when your kids don’t want to kiss you – particularly on the lips and particularly your dad.It’s part and parcel of growing up that your kids don’t even want you to breathe, let alone kiss them.In fact, everything you do embarrasses them. But, given that Kirk Douglas is , maybe it’s just a reminder that things come full circle.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: apprentice airline best episode years
story: It split apart million years ago and, must confess, it had entirely escaped my notice before Wednesday night — when it became the fourth-worst ever suggestion for the name of an airline, behind Black Box, Crash Positions and Ryanair.Or it was until Sabrina, from team Collaborative, came up with something that was worse than all of them — Jet Pop Airlines — and added a little explosion in the logo, just to set passengers’ minds fully at rest.No one involved should beat themselves up over any of these decisions, though, as they helped create the best episode of The Apprentice in years.It probably needed to be, as well. I sense, like the recently axed Big Brother and The X Factor, it’s been living off its reputation for a couple of years.Enjoyable as it’s been, the basic issue with this run has been the lack of a central figure in the mould of Syed Ahmed, Katie Hopkins or the late, great Stuart Baggs to take the series by the scruff of the neck.Some have shown vague promise but the closest thing it’s had to an alpha bell-end is Captain Pangea himself, Kurran Pooni, who was marked out less by his all-round uselessness than by the wrist he broke arm-wrestling back at the house, and his insistence he was “ per cent stepping up as project manager” just before he  per cent stepped down.There was no dodging the bullet, though, last week, when Lord Sugar demanded he PM a marketing campaign “for a noo airline” with accompanying adverts “and a noo unorm as well”.Kurran wasn’t underselling the sense of destiny he felt at this responsibility. “Everything in my le has led to this moment,” he claimed, presumably ’cos he hadn’t done anything  up until that moment.The great thing about this task, though — like all the best Apprentice episodes — was that the laughs were shared round equally.So while advert director Kurran was recreating the Club Tropicana video on Southend seafront, Camilla and Jackie were designing a stewardess’s unorm for the party-themed Jet Pop that wouldn’t see the light of day eveneasyJet suddenly opened a brothel chain in Amsterdam.A horrible thought occurred, though, as she was market-researching at Heathrow.She’s not going to wear that thing pitching to  industry experts at BA HQ, is she  She bloody is, you know.She gave it the full doors-to-manual flirtation as well. So everyone’s mind was already in the gutter before Jackie finished the audience off with the news: “It’s very easy to wipe down, as well.”In the normal course of events, reducing Claude Littner to a helpless giggling wreck would be enough to lose any task.The other team, though, Typhoon, had contrived to come up with something almost as bad, Manage Air, a business-targeted operation whose corporate logo looked like a satanic pentangle and theme tune was AC DC’s Highway To Hell.There was a genuine sense of tension in the boardroom then, which would’ve been ruinedSugar had played it all for laughs.He didn’t, though. He let the contestants hang themselves with their own words before firing Kurran, who could leave with a sense of “job done”.He’s created a bit of Apprentice folklore, after all, and hopefully reminded everyone this show is far from dead.Naturally, in the final taxi scene, he also remained convinced of his genius, boldly declaring: “My advert was gold.”The first and possibly last time in his le where he’s not just  per cent wrong, he’s  per cent right as well.Glorious television.Dianne: “Stephen Fry.”The Time It Takes, Joe Lycett: “Sesame Street’s Big Bird lives in what street ”Oliver: “I don’t know.”Joe Lycett: “A bird in the hand is worth two in the what ”Jon: “Foot.”And Bradley Walsh: “Which former EastEnders star presents the Sky One series Extreme World ”Zoe: “Barbara Windsor.”CELEBRITY Hunted contestant and former Commando Johnny Mercer MP has faced a stark choice this past month.The eternal humiliation of being beaten by Chris and Kem, off Love Island, on the Channel  hide ’n’ seek game.Or two weeks in a confined space with a clearly smitten Kay Burley.Heroically, he chose the latter, enduring her attention and pet namewith the same sort of grit that probably saw him through three tours of Afghanistan.Then, last week, he sneaked off for an unscheduled visit to his we, Felicity, and Burley completely lost her s***.Lost it so badly, in fact, that she threw herself at the mercy of a passing bread truck driver, which led to the best update of the series: “Kay Burley is currently in a -ton lorry, on the M, between junction  and .”She was quickly grassed up, of course, then apprehended at the Warburton’s depot, without the need for a vet or a tranquilliser dart.But while it’s a poorer show without the old mad-whack, there’s still plenty of mileage left in this gripping series.AJ Pritchard is cornered in Shropshire, Olympic silver medallist Louis Smith has just been found hiding in his mate’s Jacuzzi showroomand Baldrick-brained duo Chris  Kemhave somehow given everyone the slip.But as for Johnny Mercer  He’s probably smuggling himself back to the Mouth of Hell fort, in southern Helmand, just for the relative peace and quiet. Paul Merson: “For me it’s six and a half of one and a dozen of the other.”Graeme Souness: “The only one with potential is Martial and Pogba.”Dion Dublin: “Liverpool are in second and a half gear.”And Charlie Nicholas: “Pogba’s either brilliant or a showpony. He played OK last week.”THIS week’s Doctor Who episode introduced us to the Demons Of The Punjab, who turned out to be nothing of the sort.They were just morbid sods who mope around the universe “honouring those who die alone”, like soldiers, holy men and Brendan O’Carroll on For Facts Sakes.No actual science-fiction storyline to speak of then.But that’s not really the point of this viewer-shedding series, which has already got on its high horse about sexism, Donald Trump, American segregationist racism, men giving birth and gun control.Kind of inevitable, then, that the BBC would eventually pour a bucket of its self-loathing sick all over the British Empire, via the partition of India in , with an episode that was every bit as historically powerful as Carry On Up The Khyber.The key dference, of course, was that Bungdit Din and his Burpers weren’t actually being used as a means of brainwashing children.Because If you were expecting Doctor Who to present the flip side of Britain’s relatively benign rule in India , then you’ll also be waiting for the episode where Jodie Whittaker lands in a Soviet gulag and starts teaching children about the brutal idiocy of Marxism.The BBC just doesn’t do anything other than its own left-of-centre view, these days – or irony by the sounds of things.As it’s just been revealed there’ll be no festive episode of Doctor Whobecause it’s “run out” of storylines.Run out  RUN OUT How the hell can a series run out of ideas when it hasn’t had any yet This Morning, Thursday: “Coming up, at quarter to , the rise of the penis filler, Doctor Ranj is here to answer your questions.”The show’s other penis filler, Martin Lewis, will answer them on Monday.IT seems almost wrong to single out just one programme from Sunday’s beautul Armistice Day coverage, but the year’s most meaningful TV awards should probably all go to BBC’s They Shall Not Grow Old, made by Peter Jackson, whose astonishing film gave a voice, laughter, tears and colour to some of the extraordinary men who survived the - trenches.Those of us who watched it, on Sunday, are unlikely ever to forget the experience. title: martin lewis free financial education textbook
story: Well, no, actually. It’s far more important than that. Money is an issue of wellbeing.Financial problems are one of the biggest contributors to orce, mental health issues, losing the roof over your head, custody of children and even suicide. And our nation has a real problem with financial capability.That’s why I passionately believe all our children should have financial education at school. While some may say it’s the parents’ responsibility, that doesn’t work when so many parents are struggling to understand financial issues themselves.In , I was involved in leading the successful campaign to get financial education on the English national curriculum, split across Maths and Personal, Social, Health and Economic education .It hasn’t made much dference. The Government put no resources into it.So we kept campaigning. Last year the Government said it would love to see a textbook, but couldn’t or wouldn’t fund it.So I made a donation to cover all costs to the Young Money charity. And last week, , free copies of the first curriculum-mapped financial education textbook Your Money Matters was sent to every English state school .It covers saving, budgeting, borrowing, working, tax, student finance, risk and reward, security and fraud and a lot more. It’s also available as a free PDF.I’ve been surprised at how many grown-ups have downloaded it to go through it with their kids, but ended up telling me they’ve learned something too.Companies spend billions advertising, marketing and teaching their staff to sell, yet we don’t get ANY buyers’ training. title: virgin bride for sale facebook
story: The teen was married to businessman Kok Alat on November  after a bidding war ensued in South Sudan on the social media  between five men, including a high-ranking government official.One of we were neighbours.“I promised the family to marry her since she was still young.”Alat was declared the winner on August  after the teen’s father accepted  cows, three V cars and £,, a spokesperson from charity Plan International said.In one photo from the girl’s wedding day she is sat next to her husband, who reportedly already has nine wives, in a white dress looking ahead with a blank and emotionless expression.Another photo from the alleged auction shows a tall expressionless girl standing next to a smiling man.The post reads: “Competition is perfectly allowed in Dinka Jieng culture.”Part of the post references her height and reads: The kids of the winner are guaranteed for NBA slots.”The post has now been removed and the family member has now been banned from Facebook after it came to their attention.A Facebook spokesman told Thomson Reuters Foundation: “Any form of human trafficking whether posts, pages, ads or groups that co-ordinate this activity are not allowed on Facebook.”George Otim, Country Director of Plan International South Sudan, said: “This barbaric use of technology is reminiscent of latter-day slave markets.That a girl could be sold for marriage on the world’s biggest social networking site in this day and age is beyond belief.“While it is common for dowries to be used in marriages in South Sudanese culture, nothing can excuse the way this girl – who is still a child – has been treated as nothing more than an object, sold off to the bidder prepared to offer the most money and goods.”Monica Adhiue, from South Sudans National Alliance for Women Lawyers, condemned the auction as shocking and sad.”She told VOA’s South Sudan in Focus: “The practice is a gross human rights violation and violates the rights of a girl.

title: record brits in work eu nationals leave
story: Job stats yesterday showed a marked sht as the economy continues to defy the Brexit doom and gloom.The Office for National Statistics said employment among British workers soared by , to nearly  million in the year to September – the biggest rise seen for  years.Meanwhile the number of EU nationals working in the UK fell by , – the biggest annual fall since current records began in . title: prince charles loves squirrels names 70th birthday
story: The Prince of Wales made the odd confession in the latest edition of Country Le magazine, in which he joked about his alarming th birthday and claimed to have all the scars that go with his age.Prince William even claims that dad Charles has given names to the red squirrels on the Queens Balmoral estate in Scotland.Charles, who is patron of the Red Squirrel Survival Trust, said: They come into the house at Birkhall and we get them chasing each other round and round the inside.If I sit here quietly, they will do so around me.Sometimes when I leave my jackets on a chair with nuts in the pockets, I see them with their tails sticking out, as they hunt for nuts - they are incredibly special creatures.Prince William was also interviewed for the birthday edition of the magazine.He said of Charles: He is completely infatuated by the red squirrels that live around the estate in Scotland - to the extent that hes given them names and is allowing them into the house!In one article, The Queens eldest son Charles wrote about his passion for cooking and shared one of his favourite recipes - pheasant crumble pie.The heir to the throne says: I got this recipe from someone I know. It is delicious.I invented a grouse one recently, Coq au vin with grouse, as well as moussaka with grouse, it doesnt always have to be lamb, in other words groussaka!Rural heroes are also featured in the magazine - from foresters to craft cheese makers.Gail Sprake, Rare Breeds Survival Trust chairman, is highlighted and says Charles began keeping Crollwitzer turkeys after she asked him why he did not have turkeys at Dumfries House, the Scottish mansion he helped save.She added: I spotted the turkeys at a subsequent meeting and the prince shared with me that he enjoys feeding and talking to them - that told me that I was in the presence of a true rare breed enthusiast.

title: meghan markle nephew royal wedding tyler dooley
